Natalie Crown, Director, PharmD Program
E-Mail: academichr.phm@utoronto.ca
duties:
Course description:
This course surveys the economic aspects of the pharmaceutical sector. The course will use the methods of economic analysis to investigate how markets allocate resources, when they work well and the role for government when they do not work well. Specific topics include the economics of the development of new drugs; economic aspects of drug insurance, economic appraisal of new drugs (“pharmacoeconomics”); and economic models of the pharmacist labour market.

Duties
•	Teaching and developing up to 24 hours of content
•	Coordinating teaching assistants, midterm(s), and final exam marking.
•	Coordinating guest lecturers, midterm(s), and final exam marking.
•	All normal duties related to the design and teaching of a University credit course, including preparation and delivery of course content and assessments; providing a list of relevant reading materials.
•	Prepare, organize, and delivery of course material, preparation and delivery of assignments; be available to students seeking assistance between classes; evaluate and provide students with feedback on their work.
Duties of this position shall be performed at the campus on which the position is located.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Applicants should at a minimum, possess PhD and familiarity with content area including:
•	Principles of economics and their applications in the health sector
•	Economic aspects of the community pharmacy sector in Canada
•	Methods of economic analysis to  investigate how markets allocate resources, when they work well and the role for government when they do not work well
•	Pharmacoeconomics
qualifications_preferred:
•	Previous Prior experience teaching material covered in PHM 213
•	Knowledge of the Quercus platform for online course delivery is required and experience in online teaching is an asset.
•	Teaching or TA experience in course with similar content.
salery: $9,442.98 for sole course instructor, will be adjusted if duties shared

application_procedure:
Please apply on FASE Teaching Assistant Management System (TAMS):

https://tams.fase.utoronto.ca/TamsPortal/posting/877

Your application must include (1) a brief statement of interest detailing how your background meets the requirements for the role, as well as (2) a resume or CV in PDF format, that describes your qualifications for the position. If you have any questions about the position, please email both Philip Asare (philip.asare@utoronto.ca) and Morgan Hooper (morgan.hooper@utoronto.ca). If during the application and/or selection process you require accommodation due to a disability, please contact Diane Giang at director.engsci@utoronto.ca.
course_enrolment: ~250 - total enrollment - each tutorial is approx. 24 students
duties:
TAs in ESC204 are responsible for leading one or two weekly design studio (tutorial and practical) sections, supporting in-lecture workshops and active learning activities, and assessing and providing feedback on student work. They must also attend regular weekly meeting(s), as well as several additional meetings (to be scheduled at the beginning of the term) related to grading assignments. To support these varied activities, course-specific training will be offered in December 2025.

Studios (2-hour tutorial and practical blocks consisting of approximately 24 students which meet twice weekly) mainly involve activities related to engineering design, and help students build skills around effective teamwork, project management, understanding unfamiliar design contexts and stakeholders, technical design and prototyping, and communication. For technical design and prototyping, TAs will also facilitate interactions between students and course partners such as the Myhal Fabrication Facility during studio: https://uoft.me/myfab. In addition, TAs will give feedback on (asynchronously) and approve student orders for parts and services from the Fabrication Facility outside of studio time. 

Each TA is expected to support one or two studio sections. There is some flexibility in exactly which section(s) you are assigned to accommodate your availability, but you will have to be available for both meeting times for your assigned section(s) each week. In addition to leading studio sessions, TAs will assess oral presentations (during studio) as well as written and other multi-media student work, including CAD models, sketches, videos and photographs of mechatronic systems, circuit diagrams, functional block diagrams, project management documentation, and other design-relevant artifacts. As part of all assessments, TAs are expected to provide constructive, actionable feedback to students to help them improve from deliverable to deliverable.

All TAs are also required to attend weekly course team meetings (two per week for the first six weeks, and one per week thereafter). Weekly course team meetings will include a debrief of the previous week’s studio activities, plans for the following week’s studio activities, lecture content overviews, and discussion of any problems that may have arisen. Meetings will be held in hybrid format with in-person attendance required except by prior arrangement. In addition, you will be required to attend some lectures to assist students with hands-on teamwork and active learning activities during lecture, and/or hold "Prototyping Support Hours" in the Myhal Light Fabrication Facility to support ongoing prototyping work.

TAs will be supported by faculty co-leads, an engineering communication instructor, and will work together to share duties relating to course logistics as part of a large, tight-knit TA team.

Studio sessions, meetings and lectures are planned to be held in-person, unless there are changes to health policies that prevent in-person course delivery. Lectures will be delivered in hybrid format for accommodation reasons; however, you must plan to attend lecture in-person as needed to support active learning. Any changes to the course delivery (in-person, online, or a hybrid of both), will be communicated by the University at a later date. 

All TAs are required to complete all components of the Myhal Fabrication Facility Safety Training (Tier-1 and Tier-2): https://uoft.me/myfabsafety.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Open to graduate students who have an APSC B.A.Sc. or equivalent, and to qualified upper year APSC undergraduate students. Students who (1) have taught or assisted in design course(s), (2) have worked on design projects with global/international context, impact or significance, (3) have prior experience with (course-based or from industry) teamwork and project management, (4) have competencies in one or more of the following technical areas (including adapting to new software/tools and navigating documentation/resources within these areas): system-level electrical circuit design (e.g.: for powering embedded systems; for signal conditioning; for interfacing microcontrollers, sensors, actuators, and digital input/output); embedded system/microcontroller programming and interfacing including familiarity with MicroPython or CircuitPython; computer programming for system development and/or data analysis (Python, MATLAB preferred); mechanical and/or mechatronic design (including CAD, casing design, and/or mechanical actuation) o traditional fabrication methods (wood and/or metalworking); digital fabrication methods (3D printing and/or laser cutting and/or CNC) or internet-of-things (IoT).
qualifications_preferred: Preference will be given to students who engage in and have a passion for Engineering Design, as well as (1) have taken ESC101, ESC102, ESC203 and ESC204, (2) have been or are currently enrolled in Engineering Science.
tutorial:
Studio TAs must be available during at least one "Studio Block" (same-numbered TUT and PRA sections, 4 hours each week), as well as during select lecture and meeting times (1-5 hours each week, meetings to be determined based on team schedules). Block 1
Wednesdays 9am-11am
AND
Fridays 9am-11am

AND

application_procedure:
Applicants should submit a cover letter, C.V., list of references, a sample of history related writing and availability by Thursday, December 11, 2025. Applications should be sent to the following form https://forms.office.com/r/VpNNB1rPN1.                

If you have any questions or your submission on the form does not work please send your application to the following E-Mail: history.cupeapplications@utoronto.ca; Subject: History Writing Advisor Application.
duties: Meeting with individual undergraduate students to provide constructive feedback on their writing, 6-10 hours per week. Training included. The advisor is required to provide feedback on structure and to ensure that proper history specific writing requirements are followed. The advisor will be assigned a weekly schedule to meet with undergraduate students.
qualifications: Qualified applicants must have proven skills in teaching writing and be effective communicators. Success in this position requires the ability to mentor undergraduate students in approaches to writing history essays and other history writing assignments, such as primary source analyses. Candidates must not be already engaged as TAs or graders for any of our History department undergraduate courses. In-Program MAs in History are strongly encouraged to apply.

Familiarity with programming interactive computer graphics / user interfaces required.

duties:
Instructors are required to: 

1. Teach a minimum of 36 hours.

2. Prepare teaching resources for each class and provide relevant materials.

3. Assess and evaluate students' work and provide a final course grade according to OISE/UT grading practices.

4. Be available for informal meetings/communications with students as necessary.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.

1. Candidate must have a doctoral degree in psychology, human development, special education or a related field. 
                       
2. Experience and demonstrated excellence in teaching graduate courses, with expertise in content area.
qualifications_preferred:
1. Individuals with demonstrated excellence and prior graduate teaching expertise with related course content.

2. Demonstrated scholarship in the area of the course topic.
salery: Minimum stipend is $9,442.98 (per half course excludes vacation pay) for a half (F/S) course.

This role involves both helping with course prep in the Fall Term and then serving as the course TA when the course is running in the Winter Term.

application_procedure: To apply, please email your CV and contact info of two teaching references to unit1app@math.toronto.edu with the subject line "application for MAT244S"
duties: This job is for an instructor in a large undergraduate course with multiple sections which may or may not have a designated course coordinator. Each instructor will perform tasks including but not limited to: lecturing, conducting office hours, preparing class materials / tutorials / tests / exams, grading assignments / exams, communicating with TAs. The exact mix will be determined by the course coordinator (if applicable) and may change as the situation evolves. You are also expected to attend the orientation meetings and course organizational meetings. Additional duties may be required as directed by the Course Coordinator (if applicable), the Undergraduate Administrator or the Associate Chair, Undergraduate. If there is no designated coordinator, there is an expectation that the different sections of a multi-section course will function similarly: they will normally have the same syllabus and assessment plan, and will have common midterm exams and final exam. Problem sets and quizzes should be common, or at least similar/interchangeable, and should operate at a similar level with a similar approach. In addition, all instructors are expected to work together with the other instructors in the course and to collaborate in creating the syllabus, determining the course structure, and creating and marking the final assessment. Normally, classes, tests and tutorials will be conducted in person.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_preferred: Senior PhD student in mathematics (entered PhD program in 2019, or earlier) or Current PDF with a PhD degree in Mathematics working in Mathematics or a related field. Knowledge of course material, being responsible and able to keep deadlines are essential. Previous experience as a Course Instructor or Teaching Assistant, in the course (or its equivalent) is an asset.
tutorial: Monday 3:00 PM - 5:00 PM, Wednesday 4:00 PM - 5:00 PM

appointment_size: Up to 10 hours
application_procedure:
Application Process
Application information is available at https://www.statistics.utoronto.ca/employment-opportunities/cupe-positions-unit-1. The deadline to submit your application is November 18, 2025. For more information, you may contact:
Angela Niazmand
Undergraduate and TA Administrator
Department of Statistical Sciences
University of Toronto
700 University Avenue
Ontario Power Building - 9160-6
Toronto, ON M5G 1Z5
www.statistics.utoronto.ca
E-mail: jobapps.statistics@utoronto.ca
duties:
Duties are in person unless otherwise indicated and will include any or all of the following:

Preparation for classes, preparation of written or audio-visual materials, designing and maintaining course websites, attending lectures, running tutorial sessions, facilitating and evaluating student engagement on online discussion boards, participating in training sessions, meeting with the instructors, teaching, leading discussions, and supervising laboratories, rating students' work, holding office hours, consulting with students (including electronic consultation), writing and grading tests, examinations and lab sets, grading essays and term papers, invigilating midterm and final exams, setting up experiments, conducting field trips, and conferring with the supervisor in charge, as required by the employee's teaching duties. Providing lectures from prepared notes for all sections for 1-2 weeks
Duties of this position shall be performed on the St. George Campus.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Required:
o	Must demonstrate to have successfully completed a senior undergraduate course in regression analysis covering course topics or equivalent
o	Experience in conducting linear regression analysis, including assessment and correction of assumptions and appropriate model diagnostics
o	Experience performing statistical analyses and data manipulation in R and R-Studio
o	Strong organizational skills and ability to maintain tactful communication with students
qualifications_preferred:
Preferred: 
o	Experience in report writing and statistical communication
o	Experience providing written and formative feedback to others or a demonstrated interest to develop such skills
o	Familiarity with scientific report structure and best practices
o	Experience answering a variety of student questions (e.g., debugging code, writing advice, writing proofs and problem solving, data analysis techniques)

Meeting Schedule: 	Lecture:	WE:18:00-21:00 (tentative)
			Tutorials:	N/A

duties:
The TA will support the delivery of lectures and tutorials, assist with student learning, and help manage course logistics. The course covers topics such as feed-forward neural networks, convolutional and recurrent neural networks, optimization techniques, medical image processing, and natural language processing, all implemented in R using Keras. Duties include:

Create rubric and grading scheme for individual coding assignments, team projects and final exam

Grade individual coding assignments, team projects and final exam based on the rubric and grading scheme

Respond to student inquiries and provide academic support as needed
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Graduate-level training in machine learning, deep learning, or data science

Strong proficiency in R and RStudio, including experience with Keras

Experience with Python

Familiarity with health or biological datasets

Prior TA or teaching experience

Excellent communication and interpersonal skills

Experience with medical image analysis or text mining is an asset
qualifications_preferred: Same as Minimum Qualifications.

duties: The Head Teaching Assistant (Head TA) is responsible for coordinating and supporting all Teaching Assistants (TAs) assigned to the course, including those involved in labs, tutorials, marking, and invigilation (LTMI-TAs). The Head TA will oversee their performance and conduct, assign and schedule tasks, prepare the necessary documentations regarding TA duties, and provide training and guidance when needed. The Head TA ensures the smooth operation of all course components, including labs, tutorials, tests, and examinations, and responds to student inquiries related to administrative matters such as course platform access, lab/tutorial procedures, missed assessments, and remark requests. The Head TA will also participate in online discussion forums (e.g., Piazza), assign tutorial questions, coordinate room assignments for in-person tests, and manage the preparation, printing, distribution, and processing of test and exam materials (including Crowdmark setup and QR codes). Additional responsibilities include collecting and integrating marks for all assessments, assisting instructors with homework assignment planning, supporting the preparation and maintenance of course materials on Quercus, contributing to the calculation and finalization of course grades, and attending regular instructional team meetings. The Head TA may also be assigned other related duties as required to support the effective delivery and administration of the course.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Possess and demonstrate expertise in the subject matter and have experience teaching (or serving as a teaching assistant in) in this or a similar course. The successful candidate must demonstrate a track record of professionalism and aptitude for instruction.
qualifications_preferred: Proficient knowledge in the physics of electricity and magnetism and circuit analysis. Must have prior experience as Head TA for very large courses.
salery: $53.92 per hour + vacation pay. Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

application_procedure: Please click on the "How to Apply" tab on our website: https://bloomberg.nursing.utoronto.ca/careers/clinical-instructor-positions/
duties:
The Lawrence Bloomberg Faculty of Nursing Program provides a full-time, two-year, second entry baccalaureate nursing education. Given that nursing is a practice-based profession, we believe that clinical experience is a vital and integral component of the curriculum, providing students with hands-on opportunities to actively apply classroom learning to ‘real life’ nursing practice under the supervision and support of a clinical teacher. Clinical Instructors (CIs) play an important role in facilitating student learning to further develop students’ knowledge, skill, and judgement. CIs are expected to support both students and preceptors in placements. CIs should be flexible and prepared to utilize additional learning modalities such as simulation and virtual clinical learning in the event a clinical day is cancelled by the organization. CIs will work closely with the Clinical Education Office and Course Faculty to develop and share resources to support the continuity of clinical teaching and student learning. CIs are required to complete all on-boarding and orientation activities required by the faculty as well as the clinical placement site prior to the start of the placement in preparation for their clinical teaching role. Ongoing support will be provided throughout the term by Course Faculty, the Undergraduate Clinical Resource Faculty, and the Clinical Education Office.  Applicants should note that commitment to the role for the entire term is needed for consistency in the development, assessment, and evaluation of nursing students.                                                                Duties and Responsibilities:                  1.  Complete the asynchronous CI orientation learning modules as required and attend the in-person Faculty-led CI orientation for NUR461.                             2.  Complete all on-boarding and orientation required by the University as well as the clinical placement sites.  
3. Familiarize themselves with and uphold all faculty and university policies related to clinical placements (e.g., CI and Student Absences, Professional Behavior).  
4.  Assist students in creating clinical learning objectives for their respective community placements that are reflective of course outcomes, clinical practice expectations and students’ level of learning.  
5. Assist in the delivery of a three-hour primary skills lab for students, in collaboration with faculty (Monday January 5th, 2026 - times to be confirmed).  
6. Facilitate an in-person four hours community simulation (dates/times to be confirmed).
7. Encourage an inquiring, theory, and evidence-based approach to nursing practice. 
8. Facilitate interprofessional and intraprofessional communication among students and all members of the health care team. 
9. Collaborate with the NUR461 course instructors to plan the weekly virtual clinical discussion sessions in alignment with the course theoretical concepts.  
10. Prepare for and facilitate a weekly online, synchronous two-hour clinical discussion with the students, reflecting on virtual case scenarios completed by the students and building on existing clinical experiences.  
11. Monitor student performance and assess student progress with meeting the clinical practice expectations for the course.   
12. Participate in weekly email communication with Course Faculty and provide a brief update and / or identify any concerns about students’ experiences and clinical progress.  
13. Ensure ongoing communication with students, preceptors, and course faculty.  
14. Provide students with ongoing verbal feedback about their progress in meeting the clinical expectations for the course. 
15. Collaborate with course faculty throughout the term as needed to deal with student clinical placement issues. 
16. Complete an online written final clinical evaluation of each student incorporating feedback from all clinical shifts that highlights their learning and progress in meeting the clinical practice expectations for the community placement.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Qualifications:
1. Excellent understanding of primary health care principles and the social determinants of health. 
2. Professional nursing experience in public health and community health, including rural and/or underserved settings.
3. Current registration with the College of Nurses of Ontario as a Registered Nurse or Registered Nurse in the Extended Class. 
4. Current membership in the Registered Nurses Association of Ontario (RNAO) is preferred. 
5. Master's degree in Nursing or equivalent is preferred; BScN is required. 
6. Previous teaching experience will be considered an asset.                                                                                                                7. Excellent facilitation, analytical, and written and oral communication skills.                                                                                                                 8. Competent in MS Office applications.                             9. Experience using online Learning Management Systems.
Note to Graduate Students:
If you are a graduate student and you accept the position, you will agree to the following:
“I confirm that I will be registered as a University of Toronto student or PDF on the date that this appointment begins. I understand that if I should cease to be registered as a University of Toronto student or PDF during the period of this appointment, for any reason other than convocation, I must immediately notify my supervisor, and my appointment may be terminated.”

duties: The nature of this position has both in-person and remote elements. Work with embedded ethics team to deliver and develop modules (designing case studies, planning breakout discussion activities, etc.) - Write parts of, proofread and edit project documents, including educational materials in Computer Science and Ethics. - Coordinate with project team via email and synchronous meetings - Review academic literature (in Computer Science Education and related fields) as references for research project.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: see preferred qualifications
qualifications_preferred: B.A. in Philosophy preferred or equivalent- Good prior knowledge of ethics, especially applied ethics - One year prior experience as a TA, normally in Philosophy department, at U of T - Ability to work collaboratively to develop effective teaching modules - Ability to promote engagement with and interest in ethics from students with no background or prior interest in philosophy. Preference in hiring goes to Philosophy graduate students (and not CS graduate students or students in other programs). CS students with minor or joint major in Philosophy during undergrad studies may apply.

duties:
May include student contact, marking/grading, other duties as required.

Please note this course is partnered with the Writing-Integrated Teaching (WIT) program. The WIT program helps instructors embed discipline-specific writing instruction into undergraduate courses to foster students’ writing development and success. As part of your TA duties, ~30 of your hours will be focused on supporting students’ writing. These tasks include receiving training on WIT-related topics (e.g., the importance of low-stakes writing, best practices for providing feedback on writing), attending benchmarking training sessions to focus on how to evaluate student assignments efficiently and fairly, holding designated office hours for writing assignments, and preparing/delivering writing instruction and resources during office hours.

qualifications_minimum: APS360 is a first level machine learning/artificial intelligence software course. The course will focus on learning through implementation of machine learning systems in labs and a project. The candidate should have strong knowledge of hands-on software development of the application of deep learning techniques to specific applications. The candidate should also be knowledgeable and comfortable working with Python, Numpy, Jupyter Notebook, PyTorch and systems built on top of these. Research or practical experience building and tuning machine learning systems is ideal. Also seeking an ability to write and an ability to understand and empathize with the level of understanding of 3rd year undergraduates.

department: New College - Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health
application_procedure: Please submit applications via the Arts and Science TA System: https://taships.iit.artsci.utoronto.ca/new/postings
duties:
BPM338H1: An overview of mindfulness as a systematic investigation of subjective experience, with a survey of classic descriptions and contemporary scientific literature. Students will explore meditative practices in class and maintain a meditation practice outside class.

DUTIES: 
Holding office hours; consulting with the course instructor; advising students about and marking course assignments; attending lectures.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: The candidate should be familiar with topics and content addressed in the course, particularly in relation to the practices and theories of meditation and mindfulness.
qualifications_preferred: Preference will be given to applicants with an understanding of, or engaged in research related to, mindfulness meditation, Buddhist Studies and/or the interactions between Buddhism and Psychology.
tutorial: Lectures: Tuesdays 5:00 PM - 8:00 PM [Note: the course delivery mode is currently Online Synchronous and the successful applicant will need to be available to attend lectures]

job_title: The Canadian Census: Populations, Migrations and Demographics
application_procedure: Please submit applications via the Arts and Science TA System: https://taships.iit.artsci.utoronto.ca/new/postings
duties:
JQR360H1S – Examines the Canadian population census through the experience of diasporic groups in Canada. Approaches the census as a statistical tool, an historical source and an ideological project of citizenship and nationalism.  Uses census data to explore mathematical and statistical concepts and to integrate numerical ways of thinking with qualitative analysis (Jointly sponsored by African Studies, Diaspora and Transnational Studies, Caribbean Studies, Critical Studies in Equity and Solidarity, and Latin American Studies).   

DUTIES: In-person or online (Zoom) teaching of skills-based labs on quantitative research methods to support lab assignments in the course, using MS Excel and online databases. Recording of skilled-based labs. 

Holding office hours 

Consulting with and attending benchmarking sessions with the Instructor 

Advising students about and marking of reading-based responses, assignments, and lab reports.

May involve attending lectures
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Ability to teach quantitative research methods to students with little or no background in statistics (e.g. data analysis in Excel; creating graphs and charts in Excel; basic statistical analysis; and use of demographic surveys in research and policy); undergraduate degree in a discipline that provides familiarity with history and theory relating to the course and experience with social science reading and writing assignments required.
qualifications_preferred: Engagement in research related to the course and previous experience as a student in the course would be an asset.
tutorial: Lectures: Thursdays 5:00 - 8:00 PM [Note: the delivery mode is currently Online Synchronous].

duties: Teaching Assistants may expect to be involved in any of the following, as requested by the course coordinator: familiarize her/his/themselves with course material; set up and manage in-person course delivery; provide student tutorials if needed; help mark tests and assignments; assist in making lecture materials and tests available to students; administer course evaluation surveys; be available for student questions by e-mail; invigilate quizzes; send reminders to lecturers and students about upcoming commitments; be present at the day of lecture to help with setup; maintain the course Quercus page; prepare quiz packages; contribute to marking quizzes, paper presentations and help coordinating marking; host Q&A sessions for quiz preparation; help lead lab tour at local healthcare facilities; other duties as required. The course will be delivered in-person.  If public health circumstances change at the university, Zoom or an equivalent, will be used to continue course delivery on-line.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: MSc students in Life Sciences programs with a keen interest in biomedical and translational research.
qualifications_preferred: Preference will be given to current LMP students.

qualifications_minimum: Enrolled in Graduate Studies in Education with expertise in the study of health and wellbeing in school contexts. Mastery of subject material in K-12 and adult-learning, teaching and learning experiences. Research focus in student and teacher mental health, wellbeing and/or holistic practice.
qualifications_preferred: Experience teaching or working in this course or a similar course is preferred. Research specialization in health and well being studies in school environments, investigation of school-based policies and practices.

job_title: Supplemental Instruction in Higher Education: Peer-Facilitated Study Groups
application_procedure: Please visit: https://cupeha.utm.utoronto.ca/dept/fgi/app/instr for detailed information on how to apply.
duties: All normal duties related to the design and teaching of a University credit course, including, but not restricted to, preparation and delivery of course content; out-of-class interactions with students via e-mail and regular office hours; development, administration and marking of assignments, tests and exams; calculation and submission of grades; and supervision of TAs/Graders (if any) as required. The instructor is expected to be fully available for the duration of the employment period. (NOTE: The mode of instruction for this course is expected to be in-person. However, if this changes for any reason, as much advance notice as practicable will be given.)

qualifications_preferred: Demonstrated experience in training teacher candidates, teacher mentors, or student instructors.
salery: $9,442.98 + vacation pay. Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

department: Department of Chemical Engineering and Applied Chemistry
application_procedure:
Please complete the TA Application here:https://tams.fase.utoronto.ca/TamsPortal/posting/774
If during the application and/or selection process you require accommodation due to a disability, please contact ugradassist.chemeng@utoronto.ca
duties: Assist course instructor with the evaluation of course assignments related to laboratories including but not limited to grading laboratory reports and quizzes, providing feedback in a timely manner, and entering grades.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Candidates should be enrolled or should have made application to be enrolled in the School of Graduate Studies, University of Toronto with strong written and oral communication skills, strong laboratory skills, clear understanding of laboratory safety, experience working safely in an experimental chemistry laboratory and a demonstrated commitment to teaching. Candidates should have strong foundational knowledge of organic and inorganic chemistry, instrumental analysis (IR, GC), and organic chemistry techniques (TLC, melting point apparatus, distillation, liquid-liquid extraction) as well as engineering communication. Candidates should also have experience with experimental design and should hold a bachelor's degree in Chemical Engineering, Chemistry, or Engineering Chemistry. Preference will be given to those with a background in Chemical Engineering due to the alignment with the course objectives and content.
qualifications_preferred: Previous experience with marking and grading laboratory reports would be an asset.
salery: $53.92 per hour + vacation pay. Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

application_procedure: Applications for consideration must be submitted at this portal https://www.utsc.utoronto.ca/webapps/cupehiring/
duties: MUST be available to carry out tutorials, office hours, and a weekly TA training/tutorial planning session on campus, at UTSC (training is part of the paid contract hours). The timing of this meeting is TBA at the start of term, Monday afternoons are the default time slot. This means the successful applicant will need to be available on campus up to 3 times per week. General duties include conducting weekly tutorial sessions; holding office hours; grading quizzes, tests, assignments & exams, and attending the weekly mentoring sessions; other duties as required by the course.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Solid knowledge of C programming, good understanding of the memory model and of memory management in C for dynamic data structures at a technical level. Thorough familiarity with all topics covered in the course including ADTs, data structures, complexity, sorting, binary trees, recursion, graphs, and software design plus the basics of C programming. Enthusiasm for teaching beginners and ability to handle interactive (problem solving) tutorials and labs (inverted classroom style). These paid positions are open only to University of Toronto Students who have demonstrated a sound knowledge of the relevant subject matter and who have the ability to impart that knowledge to other students. All contracts are by session and extend for four months each as per the length of each session. Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.

application_procedure: Applications for consideration must be submitted at this portal https://www.utsc.utoronto.ca/webapps/cupehiring/
duties:
This position is dedicated to designing, implementing, maintaining, and improving the automarking systems used to evaluate programming assignments for CSCB63H3. The successful candidate will ensure that assignment submissions can be compiled, executed, and automatically graded for correctness, performance, and complexity using both unit and integration test frameworks (e.g., marker/unittest systems in C or Python).
You will work closely with the instructor to: Design and implement automarkers for C/C++ assignments involving data structures such as AVL trees, heaps, and graphs. Write unit tests and integration tests (e.g., using frameworks like marker.h or unittest.h) to validate correctness and complexity.  Ensure proper compilation, memory management, and edge case handling for all student submissions. Maintain configuration files (config.yml, Makefiles, etc.) for automarker pipelines. Run test scripts to verify reliability and consistency of grading. Debug and update test harnesses when assignment requirements evolve.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Previous experience running and using CSCB63 automarkers (including working with the marker or unittest testing frameworks) is required.

Strong understanding of data structures and algorithms covered in CSCB63, including AVL trees, heaps, hash tables, disjoint sets, and graph traversal algorithms.

Previous experience with CSCB63 assignments and exercises is required.

department: Department of Chemical Engineering and Applied Chemistry
application_procedure:
Please complete the TA Application here:https://tams.fase.utoronto.ca/
If during the application and/or selection process you require accommodation due to a disability, please contact ugradassist.chemeng@utoronto.ca
duties: The TA will be working with the professor to conduct tutorials, grading of assessments, quizzes and exams and invigilation of assessments, quizzes and exams. All duties are expected to be delivered in person. Meetings will also be available in-person if something to discuss.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Candidates should be enrolled or should have made application to be enrolled in the School of Graduate Studies, University of Toronto with strong written and oral communication skills and a demonstrated commitment to teaching. Candidates should hold a bachelor's degree in Engineering or Arts and Science, with a degree in Chemical Engineering, Materials Science or Chemistry being preferred. Preference will be given to those with a background in Chemical Engineering due to the alignment with the course objectives and content.
qualifications_preferred: MASc or PhD candidate, preferably in Chemical Engineering and Applied Chemistry and having familiarity with organic chemistry, applied organic chemistry or organic based chemical engineering processes.
salery: $53.92 per hour + vacation pay. Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

job_title: Introductory Chemistry I: Structure and Bonding
duties: Successful applicants will: attend in-person training and weekly organizational meetings with the supervisor; supervise up to 24 students in an in-person environment; read the lab manual and relevant material to deliver a pre-lab talk for each experiment; demonstrate lab set-ups; evaluate student preparation via marking lab notebooks; grade post-lab assignments and lab exams; maintain attendance and marks records; attend benchmarking session training for marking writing assignment.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than previous experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Applicant must have completed an undergraduate degree with a major or specialist in chemistry and have an excellent foundational knowledge of core chemistry principles including quantum model of the atom, modern bonding theory, and solution chemistry;  however, senior undergraduate chemistry students at UTSC who have completed CHMB16H3 and at least one B-level CHM course with a lab may also be considered. Applicant should be familiar with basic lab techniques such as titrations, weighing by difference, and preparing calibration curves. Applicant should be comfortable with using technology such as Microsoft Teams or Zoom. 

The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than previous experience in respect of this posted position.

job_title: Introductory Chemistry II: Reactions and Mechanisms
duties: Applicant will be expected to attend all CHMA11H3 lectures in person, while logging in remotely to the asynchronous section (12-1 pm on Mondays and Wednesdays and 1-2 pm on Fridays) and answering student questions in the Zoom chat window in real-time. Applicant is expected to be in the lecture hall 5 minutes before the start of lecture (12:05/1:05) and stay for the duration of the lecture. Applicants will also be expected to hold two, 1.5 hour review sections before each term test and before the final exam. These review sessions will be held online.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
A B.Sc. in chemistry or related discipline is required.
The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than previous experience in respect of this posted position.

job_title: Introductory Chemistry II: Reactions and Mechanisms
duties: Attending training and weekly organizational meetings with the supervisor. Supervising approximately 24 students in the laboratory. Demonstrating the required lab techniques. Reading the lab manual and relevant material to prepare the pre-lab talk for each experiment.  Evaluating student preparation and performance. Completing the WHMIS training.

job_title: Quantum Information Processing : Algorithms and Software
department: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering
application_procedure: To apply, please go to: https://tams.fase.utoronto.ca/TamsPortal/posting/762. If during the application and/or selection process you require accommodation due to a disability, please contact ugta.ece@utoronto.ca.
duties: TA - Quantum Information Processing: Algorithms and Software We are seeking a highly motivated Teaching Assistant to support the development of programming assignments for ECE484: Quantum Information Processing: Algorithms and Software. This hands-on course introduces students to quantum computing through foundational theory and practical programming exercises using quantum simulators and software frameworks (e.g., Qiskit, PennyLane). Responsibilities: Assist in designing and implementing programming assignments aligned with course topics such as quantum algorithms, quantum gates, and error correction. Develop and test sample solutions and unit tests for assignments. Provide feedback on assignment difficulty and clarity. Collaborate with the instructor to ensure alignment with learning objectives. Qualifications: Strong background in Python programming. Familiarity with quantum computing concepts and frameworks. Experience with quantum programming tools (e.g., Qiskit, PennyLane) is a plus. Strong organizational and communication skills. This is an excellent opportunity to deepen your understanding of quantum computing while contributing to a cutting-edge educational experience.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Possess and demonstrate expertise in the subject matter and have experience teaching (or serving as a teaching assistant in) in this or a similar course. The successful candidate must demonstrate a track record of professionalism and aptitude for instruction.
qualifications_preferred: Strong background in Python programming. Familiarity with quantum computing concepts and frameworks. Experience with quantum programming tools (e.g., Qiskit, PennyLane) is a plus. Strong organizational and communication skills.

job_title: Coping with Complexity in Persistent Illness (Adult)
application_procedure: "Please click on the "How to Apply" tab on our website: https://bloomberg.nursing.utoronto.ca/careers/clinical-instructor-positions
duties:
The Lawrence Bloomberg Faculty of Nursing Program provides a full-time, two-year, second entry baccalaureate nursing education. Given that nursing is a practice-based profession, we believe that clinical experience is a vital and integral component of the curriculum, providing students with hands-on opportunities to actively apply classroom learning to ‘real life’ nursing practice under the supervision and support of a clinical teacher. Clinical Instructors (CIs) play an important role in facilitating student learning and providing excellent clinical learning experiences to further develop students’ knowledge, skill, and judgement. 
	
CIs should be flexible and prepared to utilize additional learning modalities such as simulation and virtual clinical learning in the event a clinical day is cancelled by the organization. CIs will work closely with the Clinical Education Office and Course Faculty to develop and share resources to support the continuity of clinical teaching and student learning. CIs are required to complete all on-boarding and orientation activities required by the faculty as well as the clinical placement site prior to the start of the placement in preparation for their clinical teaching role. Ongoing support will be provided throughout the term by Course Faculty, the Undergraduate Clinical Resource Faculty, and the Clinical Education Office.  Applicants should note that commitment to the role for the entire term is needed for consistency in the development, assessment, and evaluation of nursing students.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               Duties and Responsibilities:                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 1.	Complete the asynchronous CI orientation learning modules as required and attend the in-person Faculty-led CI orientation for NUR460.
2.	Complete all on-boarding and orientation required by the University as well as the clinical placement site prior to the first clinical shift.
3.	Familiarize themselves with and uphold all faculty and University policies related to clinical placements (e.g., CI and Student Absences, Professional Behaviour).
4.	Attend all clinical shifts as scheduled. 
4a.	Personal obligations (e.g. attending conferences, vacations, or appointments) are to be scheduled outside of the clinical shifts. 
4b.	In the case of extenuating circumstances (e.g. illness and/or bereavement) - CIs are required to notify the Clinical Education Office with the dates as soon as possible. CIs may also be asked to assist the Clinical Education Office to arrange a possible replacement instructor. 
5.	Prepare patient assignments prior to students' arrival on the nursing unit, reflective of the students' level of expertise.
6.	Assist with and assess the students' preparation for their clinical activities with attention to integration of nursing, pathophysiological, pharmacologic, and therapeutic concepts.
7.	Encourage an inquiring, theory, and evidence-based approach to nursing practice.
8.	Facilitate interprofessional and intraprofessional communication among students and all members of the health care team.
9.	Supervise and assist students with providing nursing care while monitoring and assessing students’ progress with meeting clinical practice expectations.
10.	Collaborate with nursing staff and other health care providers in gaining assistance and access to learning experiences for the students.
11.	Foster reflection and discussion about clinical learning among students during post clinical conferences
12.	Participate in weekly email communication with Course Faculty and provide a brief update and/or identify any concerns about students’ experiences and clinical progress. 
13.	Provide students with ongoing verbal feedback about their progress meeting the clinical practice expectations for the course. 
14.	Provide written midterm and final clinical evaluations of each student that highlights their learning and progress with meeting the clinical practice expectations for the clinical placement.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
"Qualifications:
1. Interest in clinical teaching and working with novice nursing students.
2. Minimum of 2-3 years of current and relevant clinical experience (adult acute care nursing).
3. Current registration with the College of Nurses of Ontario as a Registered Nurse or Registered Nurse in the Extended Class. 
4. BScN required; MN will be considered an asset.
5. Previous experience in clinical instructing or as a preceptor is an asset.

Note to Graduate Students:
If you are a graduate student and you accept the position, you will agree to the following:
“I confirm that I will be registered as a University of Toronto student or PDF on the date that this appointment begins. I understand that if I should cease to be registered as a University of Toronto student or PDF during the period of this appointment, for any reason other than convocation, I must immediately notify my supervisor, and my appointment may be terminated.”

job_title: Introduction to Nursing Care of Childbearing Persons and Families
application_procedure: "Please click on the "How to Apply" tab on our website: https://bloomberg.nursing.utoronto.ca/careers/clinical-instructor-positions
duties:
The Lawrence Bloomberg Faculty of Nursing Program provides a full-time, two-year, second entry baccalaureate nursing education. Given that nursing is a practice-based profession, we believe that clinical experience is a vital and integral component of the curriculum, providing students with hands-on opportunities to actively apply classroom learning to ‘real life’ nursing practice under the supervision and support of a clinical teacher. Clinical Instructors (CIs) play an important role in facilitating student learning and providing excellent clinical learning experiences to further develop students’ knowledge, skill, and judgement. 

CIs should be flexible and prepared to utilize additional learning modalities such as simulation and virtual clinical learning in the event a clinical day is cancelled by the organization. CIs will work closely with the Clinical Education Office and Course Faculty to develop and share resources to support the continuity of clinical teaching and student learning. CIs are required to complete all on-boarding and orientation activities required by the faculty as well as the clinical placement site prior to the start of the placement in preparation for their clinical teaching role. Ongoing support will be provided throughout the term by Course Faculty, the Undergraduate Clinical Resource Faculty, and the Clinical Education Office. Applicants should note that commitment to the role for each scheduled shift for the entire term is needed for consistency in the development, assessment, and evaluation of nursing students.
Duties and Responsibilities:   
1.	Complete the asynchronous CI orientation learning modules as required and attend the in-person Faculty-led CI orientation for NUR374. 
2.	Complete all on-boarding and orientation required by the University as well as the clinical placement site prior to the first clinical shift.
3.	Familiarize themselves with and uphold all faculty and University policies related to clinical placements (e.g., CI and Student Absences, Professional Behaviour). 
4.	Attend all clinical shifts as scheduled. 
a.	Personal obligations (e.g. attending conferences, vacations, or appointments) are to be scheduled outside of the clinical shifts. 
b.	In the case of extenuating circumstances (e.g. illness and/or bereavement) - CIs are required to notify the Clinical Education Office with the dates as soon as possible. CIs may also be asked to assist the Clinical Education Office to arrange a possible replacement instructor. 
5.	Prepare patient assignments prior to students' arrival on the nursing unit, reflective of course outcomes, clinical practice expectations and students' level of learning.
6.	Facilitate students’ application of theory related to trauma informed care, foundational nursing skills, interventions, and medication administration practices at a novice level safely and competently 
7.	Assist with and assess the students' preparation for their clinical activities with attention to integration of nursing, pathophysiological, pharmacologic, therapeutic, and relational concepts.
8.	Encourage an inquiring, theoretical, ethical, and evidence-informed approach to nursing practice.
9.	Emphasize and demonstrate the importance of family centered care in nursing practice.
10.	Facilitate interprofessional and intraprofessional communication among students and all members of the health care team.
11.	Directly supervise and assist students with providing nursing care while also monitoring and assessing their progress meeting the clinical practice expectations. 
12.	Collaborate with nursing staff and other healthcare providers in gaining assistance and access to learning experiences for the students.
13.	Foster reflection and discussion about clinical learning among students during post clinical conferences
14.	Participate in weekly email communication with Course Faculty and provide a brief update and/or identify any concerns about students’ experiences and clinical progress. 
15.	Provide students with ongoing verbal feedback about their progress meeting the clinical practice expectations for the course. 
16.	Provide a written midterm and final clinical evaluation of each student that highlights their learning and progress meeting the clinical practice expectations for the clinical placement. 
17.	Arrange and facilitate a short 1:1 virtual meeting to review each students’ final evaluation within a week of the final clinical shift.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Qualifications:
1. Interest in clinical teaching and working with novice nursing students.
2. Minimum of 2-3 years of current and relevant clinical experience (post-partum and/or labour and delivery nursing). 
3. Current registration with the College of Nurses of Ontario as a Registered Nurse or Registered Nurse in the Extended Class. 
4. BScN required; MN will be considered an asset.
5. Previous experience in clinical instructing or as a preceptor is an asset.

Note to Graduate Students:
If you are a graduate student and you accept the position, you will agree to the following:
“I confirm that I will be registered as a University of Toronto student or PDF on the date that this appointment begins. I understand that if I should cease to be registered as a University of Toronto student or PDF during the period of this appointment, for any reason other than convocation, I must immediately notify my supervisor, and my appointment may be terminated.”

3.	Familiarize themselves with and uphold all faculty and University policies related to clinical placements (e.g., CI and Student Absences, Professional Behaviour).  
4.	Attend all clinical shifts as scheduled. 
a.	Personal obligations (e.g. attending conferences, vacations, or appointments) are to be scheduled outside of the clinical shifts. 
b.	In the case of extenuating circumstances (e.g. illness and/or bereavement) - CIs are required to notify the Clinical Education Office with the dates as soon as possible. CIs may also be asked to assist the Clinical Education Office to arrange a possible replacement instructor. 
5.	Prepare patient assignments prior to students' arrival on the nursing unit, reflective of the students' level of expertise and clinical practice expectations.
6.	Facilitate students’ application of theory related to foundational therapeutic (e.g., health assessment, various nursing interventions) and relational skills (e.g., therapeutic relationships).
7.	Assist with and assess the students' preparation for their clinical activities with attention to integration of nursing, pathophysiological, pharmacologic and therapeutic concepts.
8.	Encourage an inquiring, theory and evidence-informed approach to nursing practice.
9.	Emphasize and demonstrate the importance of family centered and developmentally appropriate care in nursing practice.
10.	Facilitate interprofessional and intraprofessional communication among students and all members of the health care team.
11.	Directly supervise and assist students with providing nursing care while also monitoring and assessing their progress meeting the clinical practice expectations. 
12.	Collaborate with nursing staff and other healthcare providers in gaining assistance and access to learning experiences for the students.
13.	Foster reflection and discussion about clinical learning among students during post clinical conferences
14.	Participate in weekly email communication with Course Faculty and provide a brief update and/or identify any concerns about students’ experiences and clinical progress. 
15.	Provide students with ongoing verbal feedback about their progress meeting the clinical practice expectations for the course. 
16.	Provide a written midterm and final clinical evaluation of each student that highlights their learning and progress meeting the clinical practice expectations for the clinical placement. 
17.	Arrange and facilitate a short 1:1 virtual meeting to review each students’ final evaluation within a week of the final clinical shift.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Qualifications:
1. Interest in clinical teaching and working with novice nursing students.
2. Minimum of 2-3 years of current and relevant clinical experience (pediatric acute care and/or pediatric rehabilitation nursing). 
3. Current registration with the College of Nurses of Ontario as a Registered Nurse or Registered Nurse in the Extended Class. 
4. BScN required; MN will be considered an asset.
5. Previous experience in clinical instructing or as a preceptor will be considered an asset.

I understand that if I should cease to be registered as a University of Toronto student or PDF during the period of this appointment, for any reason other than convocation, I must immediately notify my supervisor, and my appointment may be terminated.”

job_title: Introduction to Acute Care Nursing: Adult
application_procedure: "Please click on the "How to Apply" tab on our website: https://bloomberg.nursing.utoronto.ca/careers/clinical-instructor-positions
duties:
The Lawrence Bloomberg Faculty of Nursing Program provides a full-time, two-year, second entry baccalaureate nursing education. Given that nursing is a practice-based profession, we believe that clinical experience is a vital and integral component of the curriculum, providing students with hands-on opportunities to actively apply classroom learning to ‘real life’ nursing practice under the supervision and support of a clinical teacher. Clinical Instructors (CIs) play an important role in facilitating student learning and providing excellent clinical learning experiences to further develop students’ knowledge, skill, and judgement. 

CIs should be flexible and prepared to utilize additional learning modalities such as simulation and virtual clinical learning in the event a clinical day is cancelled by the organization. CIs will work closely with the Clinical Education Office and Course Faculty to develop and share resources to support the continuity of clinical teaching and student learning. CIs are required to complete all on-boarding and orientation activities required by the faculty as well as the clinical placement site prior to the start of the placement in preparation for their clinical teaching role. Ongoing support will be provided throughout the term by Course Faculty, the Undergraduate Clinical Resource Faculty, and the Clinical Education Office. Applicants should note that commitment to the role for each scheduled shift for the entire term is needed for consistency in the development, assessment, and evaluation of nursing students.
Duties and Responsibilities:
1.	Complete the asynchronous CI orientation learning modules as required and attend the in-person Faculty-led CI orientation for NUR371.

3.	Familiarize themselves with and uphold all faculty and University policies related to clinical placements (e.g., CI and Student Absences, Professional Behaviour).

b.	In the case of extenuating circumstances (e.g. illness and/or bereavement) - CIs are required to notify the Clinical Education Office with the dates as soon as possible. CIs may also be asked to assist the Clinical Education Office to arrange a possible replacement instructor. 
5.	 Prepare patient assignments prior to students' arrival on the nursing unit, reflective of the students' level of expertise.
6.	Facilitate students’ application of theory related to foundational therapeutic (e.g., health assessment, various nursing interventions, such as medication administration and IV management) and relational skills (e.g., therapeutic relationships).
7.	Assist with and assess the students' preparation for their clinical activities with attention to integration of nursing, pathophysiological, pharmacologic and therapeutic concepts.
8.	Encourage an inquiring, theory and evidence-informed approach to nursing practice.
9.	Facilitate interprofessional and intraprofessional communication among students and all members of the health care team.
10.	Directly supervise and assist students with providing nursing care while also monitoring and assessing their progress meeting the clinical practice expectations. 
11.	Collaborate with nursing staff and other healthcare providers in gaining assistance and access to learning experiences for the students.
12.	Foster reflection and discussion about clinical learning among students during post clinical conferences
13.	Participate in weekly email communication with Course Faculty and provide a brief update and/or identify any concerns about students’ experiences and clinical progress. 
14.	Provide students with ongoing verbal feedback about their progress meeting the clinical practice expectations for the course. 
15.	Provide a written midterm and final clinical evaluation of each student that highlights their learning and progress meeting the clinical practice expectations for the clinical placement. 
16.	Arrange and facilitate a short 1:1 virtual meeting to review each students’ final evaluation within a week of the final clinical shift.

Must have scored A or higher in MGEA02H3 (ECMA04) and MGEA06H3 (ECMA06) (or equivalent).  Preference will be given to applicants who have excellent grades (say A- or above) in upper level macroeconomics related courses such as MGEB05/MGEB06, MGEC06, MGEC61, and/or MGEC71. Applicants must have mastered the course material and be able to answer student questions related to the course content.

Applicants must have outstanding English language communication abilities (both oral and written) and have the ability to provide written feedback to submitted work.

duties: Must be able to be physically present regularly (2 days a week at minimum!) on the UTM campus to lead weekly labs/tutorials, office hours, meetings with the instructor, etc. Applicants must explicitly indicate their in-person availability, not remote availability in the application system. Applicants who do not meet these availability requirements will not be considered. Most positions will require TAs to be able to commute regularly to the UTM campus to lead weekly labs. Other duties include office hours, marking assignments, tests and exams, holding office hours, and answering student questions on Piazza. Labs will be graded weekly, so there is an expectation to be able to turn around ~3 hours of grading in ~5 days on a weekly basis.

qualifications_minimum:
Good understanding of basic Machine Learning methods (e.g., cross-validation, linear regression, logistic regression, decision trees, naive Bayes, gradient descent, neural nets, mixture of Gaussians, ensemble methods, PCA, reinforcement learning). Good knowledge of calculus, linear algebra and basic probability. Programming experience with Python, Numpy and scikit-learn. Expertise with the CSC311 content, and beyond. Strong grades in a minimum of 3.0 FCEs of CSC courses from UTM, including at least 1.0 FCEs of machine learning courses. Note that CSC-like courses offered in different departments do not count towards the FCE requirement as the courses offered in other departments or in other campuses differ widely in content, coverage, or expectations.
Must be familiar with this course offering from UTM and the UTM compute infrastructure. Strong organizational skills and strong written/spoken English communication skills, including a demonstrated and consistent ability to complete work on time and with a high level of attention to detail.

duties: Hold weekly tutorials; hold regular office hours and respond to students’ inquiries via email/Quercus; promptly grade and offer students detailed feedback on assignments, tests and exams; invigilate exams; engage with students with diverse needs and experiences in a professional and supportive manner that improves the learning experience for all students, and foster an interactive and collaborative classroom dynamic. Additional duties may involve course support services, such as updating course content and information on Quercus and other duties as determined by the supervisor.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Successful applicants will be in an MA or PhD program in Women’s and Gender Studies or related discipline. Have solid prior knowledge and understanding of the subject matter as demonstrated through current research, previous coursework, or previous TA/GA placements in similar or related courses.
qualifications_preferred: Previous teaching and/or marking experience with this course or a course on a related topic.
tutorial: Tutorials will be held Thursdays anywhere from 11:00AM – 6:00PM. TAs must be able to attend their weekly tutorials.

duties: Will include some of the following: running tutorials, marking, invigilation, office hours, preparatory work, and other duties of administering the course.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Strong grades in a minimum of 3.0 FCEs of mathematics courses, including at least 1.0 FCEs of primarily proof-based courses. Note that "MAT-like" courses offered in different departments do not count towards the FCE requirement as they do not adhere to the standards of rigour used in mathematics courses. In the alternative, applicants whose portfolio includes at least 2.0 FCEs of MAT specialist classes will be deemed to have satisfied the FCE requirement. The candidate must have strong grades and demonstrated knowledge of the course content and beyond; have a demonstrated record of commitment to teaching pedagogy and student learning; have a demonstrated record of timeliness in communication and carrying out duties; and possess excellent communication skills and professionalism.
qualifications_preferred: Teaching experience preferred

appointment_size: 35 or 70, depending on the position
application_procedure:
Please prepare a single PDF consisting of:  

(1) BME’s application form which can be download here: https://bme.utoronto.ca/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/2024_BME-TA-Application.docx
  
(2) An updated CV, and  

(3) If available, proof of WHMIS and safety training. Proof of completion of EHS training can be submitted by sending a screenshot of your EHS training record.  
 
Once prepared, please submit your application via 

https://tams.fase.utoronto.ca/TamsPortal/posting/752 for LECTURE position,
https://tams.fase.utoronto.ca/TamsPortal/posting/753 for TUTORIAL positions,
https://tams.fase.utoronto.ca/TamsPortal/posting/754 for PRACTICAL positions, and
https://tams.fase.utoronto.ca/TamsPortal/posting/755 for MARKING positions.
  
If you require assistance submitting your application, please contact: projects.bme@utoronto.ca.
duties: Duties may vary according to the specific position (i.e. practical, tutorial or marking TA) but may include preparing assignments and/or problem sets and solutions; preparing/setting up lab materials; conducting tutorials; demonstrating in labs; marking and grading of lab reports, projects, tests, quizzes, and exam invigilation; coordination meetings.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Graduate student in Biomedical Engineering or other relevant discipline.  
 
Practical/Laboratory Teaching Assistants must have up to date safety training (EHS002) prior to the start of the course; proof of completion in the application is an asset. Upon hire, you will also be required to complete BME’s online health and safety training, if not already done so, and specific hands-on training.

(2) An updated CV, and  

(3) If available, proof of WHMIS and safety training. Proof of completion of EHS training can be submitted by sending a screenshot of your EHS training record.  
 
Once prepared, please submit your application via:
https://tams.fase.utoronto.ca/TamsPortal/posting/743
 
If you require assistance submitting your application, please contact: projects.bme@utoronto.ca.

Please prepare a single PDF consisting of:   

(1) BME’s application form which can be download here: https://bme.utoronto.ca/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/2024_BME-TA-Application.docx 
   
(2) An updated CV, and   

(3) If available, proof of WHMIS and safety training. Proof of completion of EHS training can be submitted by sending a screenshot of your EHS training record.

duties: Duties may include preparing assignments and/or problem sets and solutions; preparing/setting up lab materials; conducting tutorials; demonstrating in labs; marking and grading of lab reports, projects, tests, quizzes, and exam invigilation.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Graduate student in Biomedical Engineering or other relevant discipline.   
  
Practical/Laboratory Teaching Assistants must have up to date WHMIS training (EHS101 or EHS112) and Biosafety training (EHS601 or EHS602 and EHS002) prior to the start of the course; proof of completion in the application is an asset. Upon hire, you will also be required to complete BME’s online health and safety training and specific hands-on training.

application_procedure:
Please prepare a single PDF consisting of:  

(1) BME’s application form which can be download here: https://bme.utoronto.ca/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/2024_BME-TA-Application.docx
 
(2) An updated CV, and
  
(3) If available, proof of WHMIS and safety training. Proof of completion of EHS training can be submitted by sending a screenshot of your EHS training record.

application_procedure: To apply, please email your CV and contact info of two teaching references to unit1app@math.toronto.edu with the subject line "application for MAT235Y-SINIF".
duties: This job is for an instructor in a large undergraduate course with multiple sections.  The instructor will be a member of a coordinated team with a designated course coordinator.  Each instructor will perform tasks including but not limited to: lecturing, conducting office hours, preparing class materials / tutorials / tests / exams, grading assignments / exams, communicating with TAs.  The exact mix will be determined by the course coordinator and may change as the situation evolves. You are also expected to attend the orientation meetings and course organizational meetings. Additional duties may be required as directed by the Course Coordinator, the Undergraduate Administrator or the Associate Chair, Undergraduate.   Normally, classes and tutorials will be conducted synchronously online during the scheduled lecture and tutorial times, respectively. There should be no synchronous activities outside of the scheduled lecture and tutorial hours. Final Exam is expected to be conducted in person.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Senior PhD student in mathematics (entered PhD program in 2020, or earlier) or Current PDF with a PhD degree in Mathematics working in Mathematics or a related field. Knowledge of course material, being responsible and able to keep deadlines are essential. Recent previous experience as a Course Instructor or Teaching Assistant, in the course is an asset.

job_title: An Introduction to Statistical Reasoning and Data Science
application_procedure:
Application information is available at https://www.statistics.utoronto.ca/employment-opportunities/cupe-positions-unit-1. 
The deadline to submit your application is September 26, 2022. For more information, you may contact: Angela Niazmand, Undergraduate and TA Administrator, Department of Statistical Sciences, University of Toronto
700 University Ave- Rm 9160- 6, Ontario Power Building, Toronto, ON M5G 1Z5, www.statistics.utoronto.ca, E-mail: jobapps.statistics@utoronto.ca

If during the application and/or selection process you require accommodation due to a disability, please contact
jobapps.statistics@utoronto.ca
This job is posted in accordance with the CUPE 3
duties:
Duties are in person unless otherwise indicated. Duties will include any or all of the following: attending lectures, running 
tutorial sessions, facilitating and evaluating student engagement on on-line discussion boards, participating in training 
sessions, meeting with the instructors, holding office hours, grading student homework including written reports, and 
assisting with grading of tests and exams.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than previous experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Senior undergraduate students (third and fourth year) with strong background in statistics and exemplary communication skills may also be considered.
qualifications_preferred: Graduate student with strong background in statistics, as well as excellent communication and writing skills, and the ability to interact well with undergraduate students.
